label.text: Carbon Sources and Sinks
Carbon is an essential element for living organisms.
Carbon is released and absorbed between the atmosphere and organisms as part of the carbon cycle.
Carbon sinks are places that absorb more carbon dioxide from the atmosphere than they release. For example, forests are carbon sinks.
Carbon sources release more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere than they absorb. For example, emissions from burning fossil fuels are a carbon source.
Which of these processes is a part of a natural carbon sink?
transpiration
photosynthesis
evaporation
precipitation
Which of the following human activities cause an increase in the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere?
Select all correct answers.
planting trees to restore ecosystems
using vehicles powered by fossil fuels
clearing land for large numbers of livestock to graze
improving the insulation properties of new and existing buildings
Ocean and coastal ecosystems are carbon sinks.
Which of the following characteristics of ocean and coastal ecosystems make them effective carbon sinks?
Select all correct answers.
an abundance of oxygen-consuming organisms
the presence of light and a sustained supply of nutrients
wind and tides that can be used as a source of renewable energy
the capacity to produce a sustainable yield of food for human consumption
the presence of phytoplankton (photosynthetic marine algae and bacteria)
The total amount of CO₂ in the atmosphere changes during the year according to a seasonal cycle.
Which one of these observations is the most likely explanation for this seasonal cycle?
Plant growth is higher in summer than in winter.
Many animals hibernate in winter.
Human activity is higher in summer than in winter.
The Sun is closer to Earth in summer than in winter.
Soil absorbs CO₂ from Earth’s atmosphere and stores it as soil organic carbon (SOC).
Agricultural land use and land-management practices affect the levels of SOC.
For example, planting annual crops can decrease SOC levels. This is because the crops have a short life span, leading to a rapid return of CO₂ to the atmosphere.
In the past, it was usual to burn the crop stubble. Stubble is the part of the plant remaining in the fields after harvesting.
Now stubble is often retained.
Explain how retaining stubble could help to increase SOC levels.
